passages.text: Key takeaways from J.P. Morgan's Asia Tech Tour
We hosted Alchip at J.P. Morgan's Asia Tech Tour. Key takeaways are:

- \(\) 4-6bn project lifetime contribution from 3nm AI accelerator project:\(A major focus for investors is still on the 3nm AI accelerator project. Management expects shipments to begin in late 1Q26 and extend into 2028, with total project revenue likely reaching US\) 4-6bn, excluding HBM. Although there is a trend for end customers to bypass design service providers and place orders directly with foundries, we believe allocation discussions are ongoing, and Alchip could likely handle the vast majority of the orders. While there is ongoing debate between Alchip and its major US peer regarding this project, management's comments align with our supply chain checks, indicating Alchip as the final selected design service partner.

- 2nm AI accelerator project kicking-in in 4Q: For the next-generation 2nm AI accelerator project, while the final decision is pending, the company appears quite confident about winning the project. NRE revenue is expected to begin by the end of this year, but management highlighted that multiple tape-outs will be needed due to the complex design. Mass production is likely to be in 2028 at the earliest. Despite investor concerns about third-party IP readiness affecting Alchip's competitive advantage, management expressed strong confidence in its third party partners' IP readiness, noting that AI accelerators are a fast-growing market and a key focus for allocating IP resources among leading IP vendors including Synopsys and Cadence. In addition, management believes that key clients will stick with the same vendor for multiple design cycles to save turnaround time and benefit from smoother communication between engineering teams.

- Competing for another CSP on AI accelerator project: While the project is still in the vendor selection stage and no decision has been made yet, management expressed optimism about being invited to compete. According to management, the project is highly complex, involving 3.5D packaging. The main competitors are Broadcom, MediaTek, and likely Marvell. We believe this project is likely for a US social media CSP's AI ASIC, but we don't expect Alchip to have a high chance of winning this project given the complexity of the project (likely using 3.5D IC) and the engagement model (PD1 or RTL/netlist-in may require far higher resources, in our view.

- AutoADAS project on track with more engagements ongoing: A major ADAS project with a Chinese EV maker (we believe is Li Auto) will commence in 4Q25, with growth into 2026. Management indicated the project could generate \(300 - 400nm\) in revenue in 2026 (10-15% of 2026 revenue on our estimate). The next generation, still at 5nm, is also likely to commence design work quite soon. In addition, the company is engaging with additional Chinese automakers, with no confirmation of design wins yet. While auto project sizes can't compare to major CSPs, margins are likely much better (we estimate 25+% GMs) since automakers lack chip design experience and rely
3661. TW, 3661 TT Price (28 Aug 25):NT\ \(4,000.00 Price Target (Jun- 26):NT\) 4,750.00
more on design service providers like Alchip.

- Crypto - strong demand but uncertainties in supply: While crypto demand has been relatively positive recently, with management noting significant observed volumes, supply remains a major bottleneck. Securing sufficient 3nm capacity is challenging, as foundries prioritize AI demand over crypto. Management also highlighted the uncertainties surrounding crypto contributions. We have penciled in a \(70 - 100\mathrm{nm}\) annual contribution from crypto for 2025-26, but believe some upside is possible if Alchip is able to secure more foundry capacity.

- More muted 2H25 but bright 2026 ahead: The company expects 2026 to be a better year, with turnkey revenue contributions from the 3nm project and a fruitful NRE pipeline. Conversely, 2025 may be more muted, with reduced momentum in 2H25 due to the conclusion of the 7nm project in 1Q25 and weaker-than-expected shipments from a major US IDM project (likely to EOL by YE25). We believe near-term revenue weakness is well-known, and investors remain focused on the size of the 3nm AI ASIC project and any new project wins for current and additional AI ASIC clients.

- Strategy to build a stronger alliance among IP and design vendors: As AI accelerator chips become more complex, Alchip has partnered with various vendors to offer more comprehensive solutions and improve project win chances. Recently announced partnerships include Astera Labs, with more to come (likely in the CPO space), as per management comments. Management shared that the startups are eager to work with Alchip to leverage its relationships with large CSPs and would also rely on Alchip's physical design for the projects. We believe these alliances will strengthen Alchip's ability to bid on complex AI projects while maintaining flexibility in offering different levels of turnkey solutions. As large ASIC projects become more cost focused, the disaggregated approach (IP, front-end design and back-end design services all coming from different vendors) could become more sought after, which should benefit Alchip.
Alchip Technologies (Overweight; Price Target: NT\ \(4,750.00)\)

We are OW on Alchip given confidence in regaining the third generation U.S. CSP AI project and a strong N3 and N2 pipeline. While 2025 may see a decline due to the scale- down of earlier projects, we expect to see significant growth in 2026 with the ramp- up of the U.S. CSP N3 AI project and the 5nm ADAS project.

Our Jun - 26 PT of NT\ \(4,750 is based on a 29x 12M fwd P/E and reflects our higher confidence in the U.S. CSP N3 AI project win and continued strong N3 and N2 NRE pipeline. The multiple is lower than the historical five- year average multiple.

**Analyst Certification:** The Research Analyst(s) denoted by an “AC” on the cover of this report certifies (or, where multiple Research Analysts are primarily responsible for this report, the Research Analyst denoted by an “AC” on the cover or within the document individually certifies, with respect to each security or issuer that the Research Analyst covers in this research) that: (1) all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect the Research Analyst’s personal views about any and all of the subject securities or issuers; and (2) no part of any of the Research Analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed by the Research Analyst(s) in this report. For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst’s analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst’s own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock

because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
